segment.source: Handle file activation
segment.target: Handle file activation

segment.source: An app can register to become the default handler for a certain file type.
segment.target: An app can register to become the default handler for a certain file type.

segment.source: Handle file activation
segment.target: Handle file activation

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.ApplicationModel.Activation.FileActivatedEventArgs
segment.target: Windows.ApplicationModel.Activation.FileActivatedEventArgs

segment.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Application.OnFileActivated
segment.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Application.OnFileActivated

segment.source: An app can register to become the default handler for a certain file type.
segment.target: An app can register to become the default handler for a certain file type.

segment.source: Both Classic Windows Platform (CWP) apps and Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps can register to be a default file handler.
segment.target: Both Classic Windows Platform (CWP) apps and Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps can register to be a default file handler.

segment.source: If the user chooses your app as the default handler for a certain file type, your app will be activated when that type of file is launched.
segment.target: If the user chooses your app as the default handler for a certain file type, your app will be activated when that type of file is launched.

segment.source: We recommend that you only register for a file type if you expect to handle all file launches for that type of file.
segment.target: We recommend that you only register for a file type if you expect to handle all file launches for that type of file.

segment.source: If your app only needs to use the file type internally, then you don't need to register to be the default handler.
segment.target: If your app only needs to use the file type internally, then you don't need to register to be the default handler.

segment.source: If you do choose to register for a file type, you must provide the end user with the functionality that is expected when your app is activated for that file type.
segment.target: If you do choose to register for a file type, you must provide the end user with the functionality that is expected when your app is activated for that file type.

segment.source: For example, a picture viewer app may register to display a .jpg file.
segment.target: For example, a picture viewer app may register to display a .jpg file.

segment.source: For more info on file associations, see Guidelines for file types and URIs.
segment.target: For more info on file associations, see Guidelines for file types and URIs.

segment.source: These steps show how to register for a custom file type, .alsdk, and how to activate your app when the user launches an .alsdk file.
segment.target: These steps show how to register for a custom file type, .alsdk, and how to activate your app when the user launches an .alsdk file.

segment.source: Note In UWP apps, certain URIs and file extensions are reserved for use by built-in apps and the operating system.
segment.target: Note In UWP apps, certain URIs and file extensions are reserved for use by built-in apps and the operating system.

segment.source: Attempts to register your app with a reserved URI or file extension will be ignored.
segment.target: Attempts to register your app with a reserved URI or file extension will be ignored.

segment.source: For more information, see Reserved file and URI scheme names.
segment.target: For more information, see Reserved file and URI scheme names.

segment.source: Step 1: Specify the extension point in the package manifest
segment.target: Step 1: Specify the extension point in the package manifest

segment.source: The app receives activation events only for the file extensions listed in the package manifest.
segment.target: The app receives activation events only for the file extensions listed in the package manifest.

segment.source: Here's how you indicate that your app handles the files with the extension.
segment.target: Here's how you indicate that your app handles the files with the extension.

segment.source: In the Solution Explorer, double-click package.appxmanifest to open the manifest designer.
segment.target: In the Solution Explorer, double-click package.appxmanifest to open the manifest designer.

segment.source: Select the Declarations tab and in the Available Declarations drop-down, select File Type Associations and then click Add.
segment.target: Select the Declarations tab and in the Available Declarations drop-down, select File Type Associations and then click Add.

segment.source: See Programmatic Identifiers for more details of identifiers used by file associations.
segment.target: See Programmatic Identifiers for more details of identifiers used by file associations.

segment.source: Here is a brief description of each of the fields that you may fill in the manifest designer:
segment.target: Here is a brief description of each of the fields that you may fill in the manifest designer:

segment.source: Field
segment.target: Field

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Display Name
segment.target: Display Name

segment.source: Specify the display name for a group of file types.
segment.target: Specify the display name for a group of file types.

segment.source: The display name is used to identify the file type in the Set Default Programs on the Control Panel.
segment.target: The display name is used to identify the file type in the Set Default Programs on the Control Panel.

segment.source: Logo
segment.target: Logo

segment.source: Specify the logo that is used to identify the file type on the desktop and in the Set Default Programs on the Control Panel.
segment.target: Specify the logo that is used to identify the file type on the desktop and in the Set Default Programs on the Control Panel.

segment.source: If no Logo is specified, the application’s small logo is used.
segment.target: If no Logo is specified, the application’s small logo is used.

segment.source: Info Tip
segment.target: Info Tip

segment.source: Specify the info tip for a group of file types.
segment.target: Specify the info tip for a group of file types.

segment.source: This tool tip text appears when the user hovers on the icon for a file of this type.
segment.target: This tool tip text appears when the user hovers on the icon for a file of this type.

segment.source: Name
segment.target: Name

segment.source: Choose a name for a group of file types that share the same display name, logo, info tip, and edit flags.
segment.target: Choose a name for a group of file types that share the same display name, logo, info tip, and edit flags.

segment.source: Choose a group name that can stay the same across app updates.
segment.target: Choose a group name that can stay the same across app updates.

segment.source: Note The Name must be in all lower case letters.
segment.target: Note The Name must be in all lower case letters.

segment.source: Content Type
segment.target: Content Type

segment.source: Specify the MIME content type, such as image/jpeg, for a particular file type.
segment.target: Specify the MIME content type, such as image/jpeg, for a particular file type.

segment.source: Important Note about allowed content types: Here is an alphabetic list of MIME content types that you cannot enter into the package manifest because they are either reserved or forbidden: application/force-download, application/octet-stream, application/unknown, application/x-msdownload.
segment.target: Important Note about allowed content types: Here is an alphabetic list of MIME content types that you cannot enter into the package manifest because they are either reserved or forbidden: application/force-download, application/octet-stream, application/unknown, application/x-msdownload.

segment.source: File type
segment.target: File type

segment.source: Specify the file type to register for, preceded by a period, for example, “.jpeg”."
segment.target: Specify the file type to register for, preceded by a period, for example, “.jpeg”."

segment.source: Reserved and forbidden file types See Reserved URI scheme names and file types for an alphabetic list of files types for built-in apps that you can't register for your UWP apps because they are either reserved or forbidden.
segment.target: Reserved and forbidden file types See Reserved URI scheme names and file types for an alphabetic list of files types for built-in apps that you can't register for your UWP apps because they are either reserved or forbidden.

segment.source: Enter as the Name.
segment.target: Enter as the Name.

segment.source: Enter as the File Type.
segment.target: Enter as the File Type.

segment.source: Enter “images\\Icon.png” as the Logo.
segment.target: Enter “images\\Icon.png” as the Logo.

segment.source: Press Ctrl+S to save the change to package.appxmanifest.
segment.target: Press Ctrl+S to save the change to package.appxmanifest.

segment.source: The steps above add an Extension element like this one to the package manifest.
segment.target: The steps above add an Extension element like this one to the package manifest.

segment.source: The windows.fileTypeAssociation category indicates that the app handles files with the extension.
segment.target: The windows.fileTypeAssociation category indicates that the app handles files with the extension.

segment.source: Step 2: Add the proper icons
segment.target: Step 2: Add the proper icons

segment.source: Apps that become the default for a file type have their icons displayed in various places throughout the system.
segment.target: Apps that become the default for a file type have their icons displayed in various places throughout the system.

segment.source: For example these icons are shown in:
segment.target: For example these icons are shown in:

segment.source: Windows Explorer ItemsView, context menus, and the Ribbon
segment.target: Windows Explorer ItemsView, context menus, and the Ribbon

segment.source: Default programs Control Panel
segment.target: Default programs Control Panel

segment.source: File picker
segment.target: File picker

segment.source: Search results on the Start screen
segment.target: Search results on the Start screen

segment.source: Match the look of the app tile logo and use your app's background color rather than making the icon transparent.
segment.target: Match the look of the app tile logo and use your app's background color rather than making the icon transparent.

segment.source: Have the logo extend to the edge without padding it.
segment.target: Have the logo extend to the edge without padding it.

segment.source: Test your icons on white backgrounds.
segment.target: Test your icons on white backgrounds.

segment.source: For example icons, see the Association launching sample.
segment.target: For example icons, see the Association launching sample.

segment.source: the solution explorer with a view of the files in the images folder.
segment.target: the solution explorer with a view of the files in the images folder.

segment.source: there are 16, 32, 48, and 256 pixel versions of both ‘icon.targetsize’ and ‘smalltile-sdk’
segment.target: there are 16, 32, 48, and 256 pixel versions of both ‘icon.targetsize’ and ‘smalltile-sdk’

segment.source: Step 3: Handle the activated event
segment.target: Step 3: Handle the activated event

segment.source: The OnFileActivated event handler receives all file activation events.
segment.target: The OnFileActivated event handler receives all file activation events.

segment.source: It is recommended that apps create a new XAML Frame for each activation event that opens a new page.
segment.target: It is recommended that apps create a new XAML Frame for each activation event that opens a new page.

segment.source: This way, the navigation backstack for the new XAML Frame will not contain any previous content that the app might have on the current window when suspended.
segment.target: This way, the navigation backstack for the new XAML Frame will not contain any previous content that the app might have on the current window when suspended.

segment.source: Apps that decide to use a single XAML Frame for Launch and File Contracts should clear the pages on the Frame's navigation journal before navigating to a new page.
segment.target: Apps that decide to use a single XAML Frame for Launch and File Contracts should clear the pages on the Frame's navigation journal before navigating to a new page.

segment.source: When launched via File activation, apps should consider including UI that allows the user to go back to the top page of the app.
segment.target: When launched via File activation, apps should consider including UI that allows the user to go back to the top page of the app.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: The files that you receive could come from an untrusted source.
segment.target: The files that you receive could come from an untrusted source.

segment.source: We recommend that you validate the content of a file before taking action on it.
segment.target: We recommend that you validate the content of a file before taking action on it.

segment.source: For more info on input validation, see Writing Secure Code
segment.target: For more info on input validation, see Writing Secure Code

segment.source: Note This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: Note This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
segment.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the archived documentation.
